Synergistic catalysis of hypercrosslinked ionic polymers with multi-ionic sites for conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates Xu Liao Investigation Writing – original draft Data curation a b Zeyu Wang Data curation Software a Lingzheng Kong Visualization Validation c Xilin Gao Supervision Formal analysis a Jiao He Visualization Validation a Dongha Huang Formal analysis Software a Jinqing Lin Supervision Resources Project administration a ⁎ a College of Materials Science and Engineering, Huaqiao University, Xiamen 361021, China College of Materials Science and Engineering Huaqiao University Xiamen 361021 China aCollege of Materials Science and Engineering, Huaqiao University, Xiamen 361021, China b College of Chemistry and Bioengineering, Hunan University of Science and Engineering, Yongzhou 425199, China College of Chemistry and Bioengineering Hunan University of Science and Engineering Yongzhou 425199 China bCollege of Chemistry and Bioengineering, Hunan University of Science and Engineering, Yongzhou 425199, China c College of Chemical Engineering, Huaqiao University, Xiamen 361021, China College of Chemical Engineering Huaqiao University Xiamen 361021 China cCollege of Chemical Engineering, Huaqiao University, Xiamen 361021, China ⁎ Corresponding author. High catalytic activity for the conversion of CO2 into cyclic carbonates requires the preparation of porous ionic catalysts with multi-active sites and high ionic density. Herein, a series of hypercrosslinked ionic polymers (HIPs) with multi-ionic sites, high ionic density and hydrogen bond donors (imino group) were synthesized through the one-pot Friedel–Crafts alkylation and post-synthetic strategies. Adsorption measurements showed that HIPs exhibited outstanding CO2 uptakes (1.80−2.97 mmol g − 1, 273 K and 1 bar). Importantly, under the synergistic effects of multi-ionic sites, high ionic density and hydrogen bond donors, the metal-free catalyst HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br showed excellent catalytic yield (99%) and selectivity (99%) for cycloaddition of CO2 with epichlorohydrin at 140 °C, 0.1 MPa CO2 in 2 h. By extending the time appropriately, high catalytic yields (styrene oxide, 140 °C, 4 h, 99% yield; 120 °C, 6.5 h, 93% yield; 100 °C, 16 h, 94% yield) were achieved at low temperature. In addition, the catalyst can be easily reused with stable recyclability. This work not only provides a new strategy to prepare metal-free porous ionic catalysts with multi-ionic sites and hydrogen bond donors but also demonstrated that the synergistic catalysis of multi-ionic sites is helpful to promote CO2 conversion. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 cycloaddition Hypercrosslinked ionic polymers Multi-ionic sites Synergistic catalysis Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction The greenhouse gas as carbon dioxide (CO2) has caused a series of global environmental problems, such as global climate change and sea-level rise [1–3]. In recent years, the chemical conversion of CO2 into value fuels and industrial value-added products has captured widespread concerns because CO2 is a readily available, abundant, and nontoxic C1 raw resource [4–6]. The transformation of CO2 and epoxides into cyclic carbonates is appealing due to the CO2 cycloaddition reaction with a 100% atom utilization rate and the produced cyclic carbonates are vital raw materials in polycarbonate syntheses, lithium batteries' electrolytes and solvents or intermediates in chemical processes, etc. [7–11]. Nevertheless, the practicability of this strategy requires materials with high CO2 capture and conversion ability. So far, a large number of catalysts have been synthesized for CO2 cycloaddition reaction, such as ionic liquids [12–15], metal halide [16–17], metal complexes [18–19], metal-organic frameworks [20–23] and porous organic polymers [24–29]. Since catalyst recycling and product separation are convenient, the adsorption ability of porous solid-state catalysts is more advantageous than homogeneous catalysts. However, the co-catalysts were required for some porous metal-related catalysts [19,30], increasing the cost of product purification and risking environmental pollution. To address this issue, various strategies have been developed to design highly efficient metal-free porous polymers for CO2 cycloaddition reaction. porous organic polymers (POPs) are proven promising materials for CO2 conversion because they feature abundant porosity, structural designability and functional diversity, and stable physiochemical property [31]. Nevertheless, the large-scale preparation of somePOPs (such as COFs, CTFs, CMPs and PIMs) [32–35] is restricted because of the use of expensive monomers and stoichiometric coupling reagents, and harsh synthetic conditions. As a type of POPs, hypercrosslinked polymers (HCPs) with low-cost, large surface area and abundant microporous were synthesized by a simple Friedel-Crafts alkylation from many monomers [36]. Therefore, it is necessary to incorporate IL units into the hypercrosslinked polymers network to obtain hypercrosslinked ionic polymers (HIPs) with high CO2 absorption ability and catalytic activity due to the nonionic HCPs lack of active sites and functional groups.HIPs are prepared mainly through post-functionalization [37–39], in situ generations of ionic sites in the hypercrosslinked process [40–42] and crosslinking of ionic monomer strategies [43–44]. Nevertheless, the direct crosslinking of ionic monomers to form uniform porous ionic skeletons is challenging due to the ionic monomers are insoluble in the solvent 1,2 dichloroethane. In addition, Wang et al. [41]. and Huang et al. [42]. synthesized a series of imidazolinium-based HIPs through concurrent Friedel–Crafts alkylation and quaternization of benzyl halides with 2-phenylimidazoline and benzimidazole, respectively. In the presence of co-catalysts, the above catalysts with high yields under mild reaction conditions. Sun et al. [40]. developed pyridine-based HIPs via the above strategy, and the 97% yield of propylene carbonate was obtained at 120 °C, 2 MPa CO2 in 8 h. Although the above HIPs exhibited high catalytic yields for CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides, the co-catalysts or long reaction time or high CO2 pressure were needed because of the obtained HIPs with low ionic density, increasing the difficulty of separation and the cost of industrial application. The main factor of the low ionic density can be ascribed to the Friedel–Crafts alkylation for constructing porous skeleton and quaternization of generating ionic sites are electrophilic reaction and nucleophilic reaction respectively, which are contradictory and result in a large number of active sites not being reacted. Therefore, it is highly desirable to introduce the multi-active sites and hydrogen bond donors into the polymer skeleton by utilizing and activating most of the reaction sites on imidazoline. At present, the HIPs with multi-active sites are usually a combination of metal and ionic sites [45–46], but the metal leaching and leftover could cause potential environmental pollution. Based on synthesis and catalysis, the development of a new strategy to synthesize metal-free HIPs with multi-ionic sites to efficiently catalyze CO2 cycloaddition reaction is highly necessary. In this work, the metal-free HIPs with multi-ionic sites were prepared through Friedel–Crafts alkylation and post-synthetic strategies (Scheme 1 ). Firstly, the polymer skeletons (HBIM(x)) with different N contents and specific surface areas were constructed by adjusting the mole ratio of benzimidazole with dibromo-p-xylene through the one-pot Friedel–Crafts alkylation. To full make use of the reaction site (-NH-) on imidazolinium, a new ionic active site was further intercalated into the skeleton of HBIM(x) through the alkylation reaction with 4‑bromo-buthyl-triethyl-ammonium bromide (QA) to obtain HBIM(x)@QA. Finally, to activate the unreacted sites of HBIM(x), HBIM(x)@QA-Br with multi-ionic sites and hydrogen bond donors (imino group) were synthesized through the quaternization of HBIM(x)@QA with hydrobromic acid. The experimental results showed that the catalytic activity of HIPs was continuously improved through post-synthetic strategies due to the positive effects of multi-ionic sites and hydrogen bond donors. The obtained metal-free catalyst HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br with multi-ionic sites, high ionic density and hydrogen bond donors exhibited high catalytic activity, outstanding reusability and broad substrate compatibility for rapid conversion of CO2 into cyclic carbonates at atmospheric pressure. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of N,N,N,N-(4-Bromo-buthyl)-triethyl-ammonium bromide (QA) The N,N,N,N-(4-Bromo-buthyl)-triethyl-ammonium bromide was synthesized according to the previously reported method [47]. A mixture of triethylamine (1.01 g, 10 mmol) and 1,4-dibromobutane (6.48 g, 30 mmol) was stirred at 80 °C for 3 h. The resulting suspension was cooled to 0 °C, the title product was washed with ethyl acetate and isolated by filtration as a white solid in 96% yield, and 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra of N,N,N,N-(4-Bromo-buthyl)-triethyl-ammonium bromide are shown in Fig. S1. 2.2 Synthesis of HBIM(x) BIM (0.59 g, 5 mmol) and DBX (0.66 g, 2.5 mmol) were added in DCE (50 mL) and stirred for 10 min, then the FeCl3 (4.05 g, 25 mol) was added and heat it to 80 °C for 24 h. The resultant precipitate was isolated by filtration, washed with methanol, and further purified to remove residual FeCl3 via Soxhlet extractions with methanol as solvent. Finally, dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 24 h to obtain HBIM(0.5), and the HBIM(1) and HBIM(2) were synthesized by the same method (x is the mole ratio of DBX to BIM). 2.3 Synthesis of HBIM(x)@QA Such as HBIM(0.5)@QA, HBIM(0.5) (0.5 g), CH3CN (20 mL) and the aqueous solution of sodium hydroxide (0.12 g, 3 mmol, 10 mL H2O) were added in the round bottom flask and stirred for 10 min at room temperature. Then the N,N,N,N-(4-Bromo-buthyl)-triethyl-ammonium bromide (634 mg, 2 mmol) was dissolved in distilled water (10 mL) and slowly dripped into the above mixture and the reaction mixture was kept at 80 °C for 24 h. The remaining solid was washed with H2O, ethyl acetate and ethanol Finally, vacuum-dried at 80 °C for 24 h to obtain HBIM(0.5)@QA, and the synthesis of HBIM(1)@QA and HBIM(2)@QA is similar to the above procedure. 2.4 Synthesis of HBIM(x)@QA-Br A solution of hydrobromic acid (1 g, 5 mmol, 20 mL H2O) was added dropwise to the mixture of HBIM(0.5)@QA (0.5 g) in CH3CN (20 mL), and the mixture was stirred and heated to 80 °C for 24 h. Finally, the precipitate was washed with H2O, ethyl acetate and ethanol, and vacuum-dried at 80 °C for 24 h to obtain HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br. The HBIM(1)@QA-Br and HBIM(2)@QA-Br were synthesized by using a similar procedure. 2.5 General catalytic procedure for CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides In a typical run, styrene oxide (SO, 5 mmol) and HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br (20 wt%) were added to a predried autoclave reactor and pressurized of CO2 to 0.1 MPa, and the reactant was heated to 140 °C for 4 h. After the reaction and cooling to room temperature, the remaining CO2 was released slowly. The mixture was diluted with ethyl acetate, and separated by filtration. The yield and selectivity were analyzed via 1H NMR (Fig. S2–S9): the dibromomethane (0.5 mmol, 36 uL) was added into the liquid phase as the internal standard after the rotary evaporation of ethyl acetate under reduced pressure, and the molar ratio of the dibromomethane (4.86 ppm, s, 2 H) to the products (t, 1 H) is the ratio of the integrated area of their hydrogens. The catalyst HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br was used for the next run after vacuum-dried at 80 °C for 12 h. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the polymers The FT-IR spectra of the as-prepared HIPs are shown in Fig. 1a, 1b and 1c, a comparative research was fabricated among HBIM(x), HBIM(x)@QA and HBIM(x)@QA-Br for more acquaintance of the HIPs structure. As shown in Fig. 1a, the C–H stretching at 2920 cm−1 of HBIM(0.5), HBIM(0.5)@QA and HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br belonged to the methylene (–CH2–) crosslinking bridges, and the peak 611 cm−1 of HBIM(0.5) was ascribed to the C-Br stretching of unreacted DBX [42]. Additionally, the characteristic peaks at around 1679 cm−1, 1593 cm−1 and 1210 cm−1 were attributed to the imidazolinium ring [48]. By contrast, a new absorption peak at 1392 cm−1 in HBIM(0.5)@QA and HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br was associated with the C–N stretching of quaternary ammonium. Similar results were detected for other HIPs (Fig. 1b, 1c). The chemical structure of HBIM(0.5), HBIM(0.5)@QA and HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br is further studied by 13C CP/MAS NMR spectra (Fig. 1d). The chemical shift peaks at 136, 131 and 37 ppm were assumed to phenyl carbons, imidazoline and methylene bridges, respectively. Compared with HBIM(0.5), the new peaks at 56, 54, 37, 31, 26, 20 and 7 ppm were related to N,N,N,N-(4-Bromo-buthyl)-triethyl-ammonium bromide (QA) on the HBIM(0.5)@QA and HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br [37, 41]. The above experimental results confirmed the presence of imidazolium cations and quaternary ammonium in the polymer skeleton. As shown in Fig. 2a, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves of HBIM(x), HBIM(x)@QA and HBIM(x)@QA-Br revealed that the thermal decomposition temperature of polymers about 172 °C, meeting the demand of the catalytic reaction. The structure of samples HBIM(0.5), HBIM(0.5)@QA and HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br was further studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses. The full survey scan XPS spectra are shown in Fig. 2b, demonstrating the Br 3d, C 1 s, N 1 s and O 1 s signals at 70.8, 284.2, 398.3, 532.4 eV. The high-resolution N 1 s showed that the imine-like (-N=) and amine-like (-NH-) were the main types of the imidazoline, and the N 1 s signals of HIPs were divided into three different peaks (Fig. 2c). The binding energies of samples HBIM(0.5) at 400.19 eV attributed to imidazolinium cations, and the peaks of 398.09 eV and 399.12 eV ascribed to the imidazoline [49]. The HBIM(0.5)@QA was synthesized through the alkylation reaction of HBIM(0.5) with QA and a new peak at 401.98 eV belonged to quaternary ammonium nitrogen of HBIM(0.5)@QA [50], showing that quaternary ammonium salts were inserted into the polymer skeleton. In addition, the N1s signal of the HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br has no obvious change compared to that of HBIM(0.5)@QA. As shown in Fig. 2d, the Br 3d signals demonstrated that the two binding energies of HBIM(0.5) at 70.64 eV and 69.68 eV were associated with the free bromide anion [40–41]. Besides, the new peaks at 67.47 eV and 67.45 eV were surveyed in spectra of HBIM(0.5)@QA and HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br, attributable to Br– in quaternary ammonium salts [51]. These results confirmed that the HIPs with multi-ionic sites were successfully synthesized through Friedel-Crafts alkylation, alkylation reaction, and quaternization. The irregular nanoparticles and layered structures of polymers are inspected by SEM images (Fig. 3). The layered porous structure is contributed to the mass transfer of reaction substrate, accelerating the rate of cycloaddition of CO2. Interestingly, SEM images of HBIM(0.5) (Fig. 3a) displayed a flower-like form by crosslinking spherical particles with each other. The quaternary ammonium salts and Br– were grafted onto the HBIM(0.5) through alkylation reaction and quaternization, and the spherical particles of HBIM(0.5)@QA (Fig. 3b) and HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br (Fig. 3c) were wrapped in a glue-like substance and appear in the block-like morphology. Similar results were obtained for other HIPs (Fig. S10, Fig. S11 and Fig. S12). Elemental mapping images of HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br (Fig. 3g–j) showed that C, N, and Br were uniformly dispersed in the polymer frameworks, indicating uniform dispersions of the IL units across the skeleton of the HIPs. As shown in Fig. 3d, 3e, 3f, TEM images of HBIM(0.5), HBIM(0.5)@QA and HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br demonstrated the dark alternating worm-like holes structure, confirming the polymer with abundant pore structures. In addition, X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (Fig. S13) showed that the prepared HIPs were amorphous. As shown in Fig. 4a, the porosity of HBIM(x), HBIM(x)@QA and HBIM(x)@QA-Br were measured by N2 sorption. The pore size distribution of polymers was examined by the NLDFT model in Fig. 4b, demonstrating that the HIPs have narrowly distributed micropores concentrated around 1 nm. In addition, minority polymers have mesopores that appeared at 2 − 3 nm. The hierarchical micro/mesoporous structures are favorable for the enrichment of CO2 and the mass transfer of reaction substrates [52–53]. The texture properties of the polymers were determined according to the N2 isotherm and the results are summarized in Table 1 . Notably, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface areas (SBET) and total pore volumes (Vtotal) of HBIM(x) can be readily adjusted by changing the ratio of DBX and BIM in the initial synthesis of HBIM(x). About HBIM(x), a series of HBIM(x) were obtained by changing the molar ratios of BIM to DCX (x = 0.5, 1, 2). The SBET and Vtotal of HBIM(x) were increased whereas it decreases the N content with increasing the proportion of crosslinker DBX (Table S1), giving the maximum SBET of 749 m2g−1, the highest Vtotal of 0.653 cm3g−1 and the lowest N content (x = 2). The SBET followed the order of HBIM(2) (749 m2g−1) > HBIM(1) (603 m2g−1) > HBIM(0.5) (320 m2g−1), and the law of N content is opposite. Compared with HBIM(X), the SBET of HBIM(x)@QA and HBIM(x)@QA-Br gradually decreased after alkylation reaction and quaternization, but a higher N content was obtained. It is worth noting that the N content of HBIM(x)@QA is higher than HBIM(x)@QA-Br because the Br content of HBIM(x)@QA-Br was increased after quaternization of HBIM(x)@QA. In fact, HBIM(x)@QA-Br has a higher ionic density than HBIM(x)@QA. When the molar ratio of monomer DBX to crosslinker BIM is 0.5, the obtained HIPs with multi-ionic sites have the highest ionic density (theoretical value =1.56 mmol g − 1), which is conducive to the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. The CO2 adsorption isotherms (273 K and 298 K, 0 − 1 bar) of HBIM(x), HBIM(x)@QA and HBIM(x)@QA-Br (X = 0.5, 1, 2) were recorded on Fig. 5a and 5b and the results are summarized in Table 1. The HIPs exhibited outstanding CO2 uptakes of 1.82–2.97 mmol g − 1 at 273 K and 1.20–2.03 mmol g − 1 at 298 K. The CO2 adsorption capacity of HIPs is associated with their ionic density and specific surface area [54]. The HIPs (x = 2) with large specific surface area showed outstanding CO2 uptakes with the values of 2.92–2.97 mmol g − 1 at 273 K and 1.97–2.03 mmol g − 1 at 298 K, which are higher than other HIPs (x = 0.5, 1). Interestingly, HBIM(2)@QA has the highest CO2 uptakes at 273 K (2.97 mmol g − 1) and 298 K (2.03 mmol g − 1) under the effect of higher specific surface area and ionic density. The same results were obtained for other HIPs (x = 0.5, 1), the CO2 uptakes of HBIM(0.5)@QA (2.08/1.45 mmol g − 1) are higher than HBIM(0.5) (1.82/1.29 mmol g − 1) and HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br (1.80/1.20 mmol g − 1) at 273 K/298 K, and higher CO2 uptakes of HBIM(1) (2.52/1.72 mmol g − 1) were obtained than HBIM(1)@QA (2.82/1.87 mmol g − 1) and HBIM(1)@QA-Br (2.51/1.72 mmol g − 1). Therefore, the experimental results showed that the introduction of multi-ionic sites improves CO2 uptake ability, contributed to the subsequent catalytic reaction. As shown in Fig. S14 and Table 1, the Qst values (26.66–37.95 kJ mol−1) were calculated by using the Clausius–Clapeyron equation. 3.2 Catalytic evaluation The prepared HIPs catalysts were evaluated for cycloaddition of CO2 with styrene oxide (SO) to form styrene carbonate (SC) under relatively mild reaction conditions (140 °C, 0.1 MPa CO2, 4 h) without the existence of any solvents, additives and co-catalysts (Table 2 ). Interestingly, the catalytic yields of HIPs were greatly enhanced with increase of ionic sites, the catalytic yields followed the order of HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br (92%, entry 3) > HBIM(0.5)@QA (80%, entry 2) > HBIM(0.5) (47%, entry 1), HBIM(1)@QA-Br (85%, entry 6) > HBIM(1)@QA (67%, entry 5) > HBIM(1) (29%, entry 4) and HBIM(2)@QA-Br (88%, entry 9) > HBIM(2)@QA (60%, entry 8) > HBIM(2) (41%, entry 7), showing the positive effects of the multi-ionic site on catalytic performance. The experimental results demonstrated that excellent catalytic activity was achieved after anchoring multi-ionic sites into HBIM(0.5), the obtained HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br with multi-ionic sites and the highest ionic density exhibited 92% yield (entry 3) for cycloaddition of CO2 with SO, which are superior to other HIPs under the same reaction conditions. Compared with HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br, HBIM(1)@QA-Br offered a lower yield of 85% (entry 6), which could be attributed to moderate specific surface area and density. In addition, HBIM(2)@QA-Br with a large specific surface area and low ionic density gave a higher yield of 88% (entry 9) and a large turnover number (TON) of 51.76 (TOF of 12.94 h − 1). In summary, HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br showed the highest catalytic yield under the synergistic effect of the multi-ionic sites and high ionic density and reflected that the ionic sites of HIPs are closely associated with the yield of the target product. Besides, we further studied the optimum reaction conditions and substrate compatibility of the HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br. The catalytic activity of CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides relies on the main factors, such as catalyst amount, reaction temperature, CO2 pressure and reaction time of the reaction system. The previous experimental results showed that HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br exhibited the highest catalytic activity for the cycloaddition of CO2 with SO. Therefore, the catalyst HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br was used to evaluate the effect of these reaction factors in the cycloaddition of CO2 with SO, and the research results are shown in Fig. 6. It should be noted that no matter how to vary the reaction condition, high selectivity is still achieved. The effect of the mass ratio of catalyst to SO on catalytic performance is investigated in Fig. 6a, it was found that the yields of SC increased rapidly from 58% to 99% when the mass ratio of catalyst to SO was increased from 4 wt% to 20 wt%. Furthermore, the influence of reaction temperature on catalytic activity is studied in Fig. 6b. The yields were increased when increasing the reaction temperature from 50 °C to 140 °C, and then it keep stable. Fig. 6c shows that the yield of SC was closely related to the CO2 pressure and the yield increased (from 25% to 87%) with the maximum yield of 87% at 2 MPa CO2. At last, the effect of the reaction time on catalytic performance was investigated while keeping the mass ratio of catalyst to SO (20 wt%) and reaction temperature (140 °C) constant in Fig. 6d. The yields of SC were improved with the increase of reaction time, achieving a maximum yield of 99% within 4 h. In summary, HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br exhibited 99% yield and 99% selectivity at 0.1 MPa CO2, 140 °C in 4 h (mass ratio of catalyst to SO: 20 wt%). To explore the substrate compatibility of the catalyst, the catalyst HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br was assessed for the cycloaddition of CO2 with various epoxide substrates. As shown in Table 3 , the HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br exhibited high catalytic yields (93–99%) and selectivities (99%) for most epoxides (entries 1–8). The high yield (entry 1, 99% yield) was achieved for the conversion of epichlorohydrin within a relatively short reaction time (2 h). Moreover, HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br can convert the large size of substrates by prolonging reaction time, and the large substrates were challenging in previous reports due to difficulty in reacting with CO2 [11]. The conversion of glycidyl phenyl ether, o-tolyl glycidyl ether, allyl glycidyl ether and butyl glycidyl ether into corresponding cyclic carbonates with 96−98% yields (entries 3 − 6) in 5 h. Interestingly, the HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br catalyzed CO2 cycloaddition with the long carbon-chain alkyl epoxide and bis epoxide in 8 h and 10 h, affording the yields of 93% (entry 7) and 98% (entry 8). Notably, achieving high yields of SC (entry 2, 120 °C, 6.5 h, 93% yield; 100 °C, 16 h, 94% yield) at a lower temperature, and the reaction time is shorter than that of most porous ionic polymers previously reported (Table S2). The outstanding reusability and stability of heterogeneous catalysts are very pivotal for their practical application. To examine the reusability of the catalyst, HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br was applied to carry out recycling tests for CO2 cycloaddition with SO at 0.1 MPa CO2, 140 °C in 4 h. As shown in Fig. 7, a high yield (93%) was achieved after running 6 times. In addition, A series of characterization including FT-IR spectra (Fig. 8a), thermogravimetric analysis (Fig. 8b), N2 sorption isotherm (inset: the pore size distribution curve) (Fig. 8c) and SEM image (Fig. 8d) of the recovered catalyst HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br that demonstrate the chemical structural composition and textural structure of HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br are well-preserved corresponding to the fresh sample. The above results confirmed that the catalyst HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br has outstanding stability and good recyclability. 3.3 Understanding the catalytic process According to the previous reports and experimental results, the plausible reaction mechanism of HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br catalyzed CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides is revealed as described in Scheme 2 . Firstly, the epoxides are activated through the hydrogen bonding interaction between the oxygen atom of the epoxides and the imino group (as well as the acidic C2 hydrogen atom) of imidazoline, and interaction between the quaternary ammonium salt (N +) and the oxygen atom of epoxides [38,42,55,56]. Meanwhile, bromine anions of HIPs as nucleophile attacks the less sterically hindered β-carbon atom, resulting in the ring-opening of epoxides to form the oxyanion intermediate that is steadied through the imino group and acidic C2 hydrogen atom of imidazoline, and quaternary ammonium salt (N +). Subsequently, the alkyl carbonate anion intermediate is formed by the inserted CO2 that reacts with the oxyanion intermediate. Finally, intramolecular cyclization leads to the production of cyclic carbonate, with the leaving of bromide anion and thus releasing the catalyst HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we constructed a series of HIPs with multi-ionic sites and hydrogen bond donors (imino group) through the one-pot Friedel–Crafts alkylation and post-synthetic strategies, the synthesized HIPs with available multiple characteristics of high specific surface area, abundant hierarchical porosities, highly dispersed multi-ionic sites and hydrogen bond donors. FT-IR, XPS, SEM images and elemental analyses showed that the multi-ionic sites were successfully inserted into the skeleton structure of hypercrosslinked polymers. Under the synergistic effects of multi-ionic sites and high ionic density, the catalyst HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br exhibited high catalytic yields (93%−99%) for cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides at atmospheric pressure in the short reaction time (2 − 10 h). This work synthesizes a series of new HIPs with multi-ionic sites and hydrogen bond donors by utilizing and activating most of the reaction sites on imidazoline for efficient CO2 capture and conversion and highlights the significance of the introduction of multi-ionic sites has synergistic effects on enhancing the catalytic activity of HIPs for CO2 cycloaddition reaction. coredata.dc:description: High catalytic activity for the conversion of CO2 into cyclic carbonates requires the preparation of porous ionic catalysts with multi-active sites and high ionic density. Herein, a series of hypercrosslinked ionic polymers (HIPs) with multi-ionic sites, high ionic density and hydrogen bond donors (imino group) were synthesized through the one-pot Friedel–Crafts alkylation and post-synthetic strategies. Adsorption measurements showed that HIPs exhibited outstanding CO2 uptakes (1.80−2.97 mmol g − 1, 273 K and 1 bar). Importantly, under the synergistic effects of multi-ionic sites, high ionic density and hydrogen bond donors, the metal-free catalyst HBIM(0.5)@QA-Br showed excellent catalytic yield (99%) and selectivity (99%) for cycloaddition of CO2 with epichlorohydrin at 140 °C, 0.1 MPa CO2 in 2 h. By extending the time appropriately, high catalytic yields (styrene oxide, 140 °C, 4 h, 99% yield; 120 °C, 6.5 h, 93% yield; 100 °C, 16 h, 94% yield) were achieved at low temperature. In addition, the catalyst can be easily reused with stable recyclability. This work not only provides a new strategy to prepare metal-free porous ionic catalysts with multi-ionic sites and hydrogen bond donors but also demonstrated that the synergistic catalysis of multi-ionic sites is helpful to promote CO2 conversion.
coredata.dc:title: Synergistic catalysis of hypercrosslinked ionic polymers with multi-ionic sites for conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates
